 1) Many children are killed every year by guns.

This should also apply to guns.
 
 2) One should rely on police to protect them.
 
 Police arrive too late to even arrest someone like 80% of the time. Most calls occur after the crime is committed, therefore all the police do is try to catch the criminal after the fact. That's not personal protection, it merely serves to protect the rest of the community after the fact. There was a case where a citizen sued a police agency for not protecting them and the police said something like "It is not our responsibility to protect citizens from every attack". It's pretty obvious that your safety is in your own hands. Do you think the criminal will give you time to call police? Are you sure they will get there in time? Would you feel safer if you had a gun when you here your front door being kicked in? YOU are the police department of your house!
 
 3) You should comply with your assailant and hope for the best.
 
 First of all, you are placing your life in the hands of someone who obviously doesn't care about anyone but themselves. You are also volunteering to be a victim, "Yes, go ahead and rape my 11 year old daughter, I most certainly am not going to do anything. Please don't kill us afterwards to eliminate witnesses, I've been nice to you." Of course there are some instances where you must comply, if they have a gun to your head and their finger on the trigger there is little you can do. If you think it is better to leave your life in the hands of a criminal than to defend yourself in EVERY situation then that's your choice, but I think you are wrong.
 
 4) People who carry guns make me feel unsafe.
 
 You have the right to feel unsafe if you want, but why aren't you scarred around cops? I'm sure it's for one of two reasons, either you think that they are more competent or you think that citizens are more prone to pulling out their guns. If you are assuming that they are more competent you are probably wrong most of the time. EVERYONE that I know who carries realizes the awesome responsibility the have and most invest MORE money in training than they actually spend on guns. Of course not everyone does this and , unlike some people, I don't have a problem with requiring more training to get a license. Did you know that police miss around 80% of the time? Do you really think that armed citizens are any worse? Police don't train as much as they should.
 
 5)People who carry guns infringe on my rights.
 
 What right, the right to feel safe based of false beliefs? Do you now that if you make them stop you are infringing on their CONSTITUTIONAL right to bear arms? They said "people" not "militia", it's pretty clear. It's OK for you to be scared of guns and not want the responsibility and training that goes along with them, but that gives you no right to take mine away.

 Well, being a gun owner myself, I agree with much that you've posted. I do disagree somewhat with your conclusions in regard to these statistics however.
 
 For example, most of the states listed with high gun crime, and gun control laws, have cities that alone rival the population of the states with low gun crime, and less gun restrictions.
 
 And that may be part of the problem. Population density may well have some consideration here. It may be a lot easier, for example, for someone to commit multiple armed robberies in a given period of time in say someplace like NYC, than it would be in a rural state like Vermont or Montana. this in turn, would more naturally increase the chances of someone being shot, because of not giving up their wallet, or attempting to resist in saome other manner. 
 
 Bear in mind, I'm not saying that this is the case. I'm saying that it may be a factor. With just the numbers you've given us, I don't think there's necessarily proof of corellation between lack of crime and relative freedom from restrictive gun laws. The likely-hood is that it certainly helps, and in fact may be one of the major reasons. I just don't think you can say it's the only, or even the main reason.
